config.topic: What happened to research on automated visualization?
config.target_audience: researchers in the visualization community, they might be interested in both topic evolution and how people in the field shape the research (such as their interactions and key players)
config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

report_outline.section_description: High-level takeaways about the trajectory of automated visualization research and the specific questions the report answers (e.g., Has automated visualization grown or declined? Which topics rose or fell? Who shaped the field?).

information_needed.question_text: Has automated-visualization (AutoVis) research grown or declined over time in absolute counts and as a share of conference output?
transformation: Filter records classified as AutoVis using the keyword-based classifier (apply the provided regex against Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords).
Group by Year (optionally also by Conference).
Aggregate: count AutoVis papers per Year (and per Conference); compute share = AutoVis_count / total_papers_per_year.

global_filter_state.description: Select all columns for papers whose Title, Abstract, or AuthorKeywords mention automated-visualization related terms (case-insensitive). This filters for keywords: automatic vis, automated vis, visualization recommendation, mixed initiative, mixed-initiative, visualization generation, vis generation, agent. Results are ordered by Year to support trend analysis.

content.text: Automated visualization (AutoVis) has moved from sporadic early work into a clearly visible strand of Vis research: our filtered corpus spans 1995–2024 and contains roughly 80–83 papers identified as AutoVis depending on matching rules, with a clear surge between 2019 and 2023 and a peak year in 2021 (16 papers). The field is shaped by a small number of influential groups and high-impact systems (for example Voyager and Draco) and by a handful of venues—Vis, VAST, and InfoVis—where AutoVis work concentrates. This report answers three core questions: Has AutoVis grown or declined? (answer: overall growth with punctuated peaks and short-term volatility); Which topics rose or fell? (recommendation systems, mixed-initiative, learning/ML and generation/agents rose strongly in the last decade, while some pipeline-focused work declined in relative share); Who shaped the field? (a network of prolific authors and institutions—including Alex Endert, Jeffrey Heer, Dominik Moritz, Huamin Qu, Georgia Tech, and University of Washington—has driven much of the activity and impact). The rest of the report unpacks these trends, the identification methodology, topic lifecycles, community structure, and implications for impact and reproducibility.

content.text: The dual-panel figure pairs per-year counts of AutoVis papers with a stacked area that shows how conferences contributed over time. Absolute counts are small in the 1990s and 2000s, rise gradually through the 2010s, and spike between 2019 and 2023, with 2021 the largest single-year surge (16 AutoVis papers). Conference composition shifts with time: early AutoVis work appeared across Vis, InfoVis and VAST, but from 2021 onward Vis becomes the dominant host for AutoVis submissions (the dataset shows Vis contributing 45 papers overall, VAST 21 and InfoVis 13). Taken together the charts emphasize both the recent growth in activity and a consolidation of venue choices in recent years.

content.text: The keyword overview and trajectory chart show which topical terms recur and how their prominence evolves in three‑year bins. Broad, content words such as data, visualization/visual, system, and user/users dominate overall counts, but their time‑series reveal the story: modest presence early on, accelerating around 2013–2016 and then a large uptick in 2019–2021 that largely persists through 2022–2024. The authors’ shortlist (visualization, this, that, data, visual, from, system) and the per‑bin counts make the surge visible—2019–2021 is a clear inflection point where many topics jump to their highest frequencies—suggesting the field broadened and matured, with sustained interest afterward rather than a one‑off blip.

report_outline.section_description: Concise description of the Vis publication dataset, the attributes used, and the precise rule for identifying 'automated visualization' (AutoVis) papers. This section will document data cleaning, the keyword filter (automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent), and the fields relied on (Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, Year, Conference, AuthorNames, AuthorAffiliation, Citation and Download metrics, Award, GraphicsReplicabilityStamp).

content.text: The dataset is a curated Vis-publication slice covering 1995–2024 with 83 records in the filtered set and standard bibliographic fields (Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, Year, Conference, AuthorNames, AuthorAffiliation) plus citation and download proxies. We identified AutoVis papers using a conservative keyword filter applied across text fields: terms such as automatic vis, automated vis, visualization recommendation, mixed initiative, mixed-initiative, visualization generation, vis generation, and agent. Records were cleaned for author/institution name variations and simple disambiguation heuristics were applied; missingness was inspected and documented. Because detection relies on text matches across multiple fields, a few papers differ depending on the exact field-match rule (the pipeline reports ~83 AutoVis matches in some runs, ~80 in others). Users should therefore treat borderline counts with caution and prefer the field-level match breakdown (Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords) shown below when interpreting results.

content.text: A field‑match analysis shows where the AutoVis label comes from: the Abstract is the most frequent source of matches (36 single‑field matches), AuthorKeywords also contribute substantially (21), Title matches are rare (3), and many papers match multiple fields (23). Yearly stacks reveal that recent peaks (notably 2021) include a high share of multi‑field matches—evidence that papers then explicitly signaled AutoVis topics in title, keywords, and abstract. The same panel surfaces highly cited exemplars (Voyager, Draco, and several others), showing that the papers most clearly framed as AutoVis are also among the most influential.

content.text: AutoVis shows a multi‑decadal arc: tiny counts in the 1990s and 2000s give way to steady growth in the 2010s and a punctuated rise around 2019–2021, then sustained but variable counts through 2024. Absolute growth is visible (per‑year counts rising from single digits to the 10–16 range in peak years) and relative changes are dramatic in some years (e.g., 2014 saw a 300% YoY increase and 2021 a large surge). Topic composition shifted in parallel: interaction, evaluation, generation/agents and learning/ML rose into prominence; mixed‑initiative and recommendation systems matured; pipeline‑oriented work declined in relative share. Overall the picture is one of growth plus topical diversification, punctuated by consolidation around tool‑oriented and ML‑driven approaches in recent years.

The timeline visualization combines total Vis papers (bars), AutoVis counts (line and points), and a separate proportion trace that—because the dataset is already prefiltered—shows AutoVis as the dominant labeling within the selection. Looking at counts and year‑on‑year percent changes makes several features clear: slow, intermittent activity through the 2000s; a few jump years (2014, 2016) and big accelerations in 2020–2021 (133% and 128% increases respectively) followed by contractions (2017 and 2022 show sizeable drops). The takeaway is that growth has been episodic and concentrated in a short window of recent years rather than a steady linear increase.

content.text: Stacked and smoothed topic views reveal changing topical composition. The five most frequent topics are Interaction, Generation/Agents, Evaluation, Mixed‑Initiative, and Recommendation Systems, each present across multiple years but with different rhythms: Generation/Agents and Interaction show long histories (first appearances in the 1990s) and remain substantial, Learning/ML and Recommendation Systems rise in the 2010s, and Explainability peaked around 2018 before falling back. The normalized stacks make it clear some topics shrink in relative share even as absolute AutoVis counts grow—visualization pipelines and some early pipeline‑centric work are examples of declining relative attention—while mixed‑initiative and ML‑related threads have broadly consolidated into the mainstream.

information_needed.key_uncertainty: Author name disambiguation quality and how to derive reliable institution identifiers; appropriate thresholds and aggregation for building a readable co-authorship network (edge weight cutoff, time-windowing); and how to assign papers to subtopics reliably from AuthorKeywords/Abstract/Title.
expected_outputs: A cleaned author-id mapping (or a recommended heuristic) resolving common name variants / duplicates and a plan to extract institution names from AuthorAffiliation (or list of manual exceptions).

A topic-assignment scheme for papers (keyword-to-subtopic mapping or simple clustering of abstracts/keywords), plus suggested Sankey flow aggregation levels (e.g., group authors by top 5 topics and show flows across two time periods) to keep Sankey readable.

content.text: AutoVis research is produced by a moderately concentrated community: roughly 300 distinct authors and about 116 institution strings appear in the filtered set, with a long tail of single‑paper contributors and a small core of repeat authors. Top authors by paper count include Alex Endert (7), Yingcai Wu (6), Huamin Qu (6), Jeffrey Heer (5), Nan Cao (5) and Dominik Moritz (4); some of these authors (e.g., Heer, Moritz) also show very high citation impact per paper. Institutions that repeatedly host AutoVis work include Georgia Tech, University of Washington, HKUST, Microsoft Research (including Microsoft Research Asia), and several national labs and university centers. Collaboration patterns form dense local clusters around these labs and a few bridge authors who connect communities; overall the field is collaborative but not uniform—several tightly knit subgroups drive much of the production and influence.

content.text: The co‑authorship network is large and modular: roughly 298 author nodes, ~887 coauthorship links, and about two dozen connected components at the chosen pruning threshold. Network metrics identify core bridge figures (high betweenness and weighted degree) who connect otherwise separate clusters, while several dense subgroups reflect strong internal collaboration within particular labs or regional clusters (for example clusters around Yingcai Wu, Huamin Qu, and some European visualization groups). The interactive force‑layout visualization emphasizes both the clustered structure and these bridging actors; operational recommendations include pruning low‑weight edges for clarity, using fractional edge weights, and reporting degree/betweenness together to identify both prolific and connective researchers.

content.text: Impact measures show AutoVis work includes several highly influential papers and a broad middle distribution: median CrossRef citations is modest (about 14) with a long tail of high outliers (Voyager ~292 CrossRef citations and even higher Aminer counts in some entries), and downloads are substantial (median Downloads_Xplore roughly 900). Awards are uncommon in the sample (award metadata is heavily missing), and GraphicsReplicabilityStamp metadata is effectively absent for all records, so we cannot meaningfully measure reproducibility coverage. In short, AutoVis contains both widely adopted, high‑impact artifacts and many lower‑visibility contributions, but reproducibility and award metadata gaps limit nuanced claims about how impact correlates with reproducible practices.

AutoVis medians (Aminer ~9.5, CrossRef ~14) and downloads (median ≈937) show the area is not only academically cited but also widely accessed. Awarded papers are few in the metadata and therefore any stratified comparisons are tentative; nevertheless the distribution emphasizes that a handful of systems and conceptual contributions account for a large share of community attention.

content.text: Replicability metadata is essentially uninformative: the GraphicsReplicabilityStamp field is uniformly unknown for all 83 records in the cleaned mapping, so plotted medians and IQRs collapse to a single 'Unknown' category. Because there are no labeled replicability stamps, no robust correlations with citation or download metrics can be computed. The practical recommendation is to prioritize collecting and standardizing reproducibility indicators (or encouraging authors to tag artifacts) so future analyses can test whether more reproducible work correlates with greater adoption or citation impact.

report_outline.section_description: Synthesis of findings, interpretation of what happened to automated visualization research (growth, consolidation, fragmentation, or decline), open questions for the community, and actionable recommendations for researchers (topics to revisit, methodological improvements, reproducibility and tooling, collaboration opportunities).

content.text: Synthesis and recommendations: automated visualization research has clearly grown, matured, and partially consolidated around a set of topics (interaction, generation/agents, mixed‑initiative, learning and recommendation systems) and a set of active labs and venues. That said, growth has been episodic—big surges around 2019–2021—followed by continued but variable activity. Open questions for the community include what drove the 2021 peak (venue changes, funding shifts, tooling like ML/agent breakthroughs), whether the field is fragmenting into subcommunities or consolidating around shared toolchains, and how to evaluate and compare AutoVis systems across work that mixes engineering, ML, and human-centered evaluation. Actionable recommendations: 1) improve metadata and reproducibility practices (collect replicability stamps, publish code/datasets/benchmarks), 2) revisit declining but foundational areas (visualization pipelines, rigorous evaluation) with modern ML/agent techniques, 3) encourage cross‑lab collaborative benchmarks and shared evaluation protocols to reduce duplicated effort, and 4) fund and document long‑running user studies and engineering efforts so the field can better assess long‑term adoption and impact. These steps will help the community build on recent momentum while making findings more comparable, reusable, and cumulative.
